TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit SingleAnimationUsingKeyFrames extends System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleAnimationBase implements class System.Windows.Markup.IAddChild, class System.Windows.Media.Animation.IKeyFrameAnimation
Public Class SingleAnimationUsingKeyFrames Inherits SingleAnimationBase Implements IAddChild, IKeyFrameAnimation
type SingleAnimationUsingKeyFrames = class inherit SingleAnimationBase interface IKeyFrameAnimation interface IAddChild

Docs.summary: Animates the value of a property along a set of .

remarks.format:
## Remarks A key frame animation's target values are defined by its <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleAnimationUsingKeyFrames.KeyFrames%2A> property, which contains a collection of <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleKeyFrame> objects. Each <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleKeyFrame> defines a segment of the animation with its own target <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleKeyFrame.Value%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleKeyFrame.KeyTime%2A>. When the animation runs, it progresses from one key value to the next at the specified key times.
There are three types of <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleKeyFrame> classes, one for each supported interpolation method: <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.LinearSingleKeyFrame>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.DiscreteSingleKeyFrame>, and <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineSingleKeyFrame>.
Unlike a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleAnimation>, a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleAnimationUsingKeyFrames> can have more than two of target values. You can also control the interpolation method of individual <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleKeyFrame> segments.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This method allows <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleKeyFrame> objects to be direct children of a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleAnimationUsingKeyFrames> object in markup.

Docs.summary: Adds a text string as a child of this .

remarks.format: ## Remarks A <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SingleAnimationUsingKeyFrames> does not accept text as a child, so this method will throw an <xref:System.InvalidOperationException> unless a derived class has overridden this behavior which allows text to be added.

Docs.exception: A derived class has not overridden the default behavior, which does not allow text to be added.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method is used to produce modifiable copies of frozen <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> objects (or any <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object). For convenience, this method shadows the inherited version with a strongly typed implementation.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.Clone%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>.

Docs.summary: Makes this instance a deep copy of the specified . When copying dependency properties, this method copies resource references and data bindings (but they might no longer resolve) but not animations or their current values.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method is called by the <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.Clone%2A> method and should not be called directly from your code, except when calling the base implementation while overriding this method. To create a modifiable copy of the current object, call <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.Clone%2A> instead of calling this method directly.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.CloneCore%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>.

Docs.param: to check if this instance can be frozen; to freeze this instance.
Docs.summary: Makes this instance of object unmodifiable or determines whether it can be made unmodifiable.
Docs.returns: If is , this method returns if this instance can be made read-only, or if it cannot be made read-only. If is , this method returns if this instance is now read-only, or if it cannot be made read-only, with the side effect of having begun to change the frozen status of this object.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void GetAsFrozenCore(class System.Windows.Freezable source) cil managed
Protected Overrides Sub GetAsFrozenCore (source As Freezable)

Docs.summary: Makes this instance a clone of the specified object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When copying dependency properties, this method copies resource references and data bindings (but they might no longer resolve) but not animations or their current values. Note that if these properties contain resource references or data bindings, <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.GetAsFrozen%2A> will fail when trying to freeze the object and will throw an <xref:System.InvalidOperationException>.
This method is called by the <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.GetAsFrozen%2A> method and should not be called directly from your code, except when calling the base implementation while overriding this method. To create a frozen copy of the current object, call <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.GetAsFrozen%2A> instead of calling this method directly.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.GetAsFrozenCore%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>.

protected: override float GetCurrentValueCore(float defaultOriginValue, float defaultDestinationValue, System::Windows::Media::Animation::AnimationClock ^ animationClock);

Docs.param: The suggested origin value, used if the animation does not have its own explicitly set start value.
The suggested destination value, used if the animation does not have its own explicitly set end value.
An that generates the or used by the host animation.
Docs.summary: Calculates a value that represents the current value of the property being animated, as determined by this instance of .
Docs.returns: The calculated value of the property, as determined by the current instance.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the `defaultOriginValue` is the first in the composition chain, this value will be the snapshot value (if one is available) or the base property value; otherwise this value will be the value returned by the previous animation in the chain with an <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationClock> that is not <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Clock.Stopped%2A>.
The `defaultDestinationValue` is the base value if the animation is in the first composition layer of animations on a property; otherwise the value is the output value from the previous composition layer of animations for the property.

Docs.summary: Gets a value that specifies whether the animation's output value is added to the base value of the property being animated.
Docs.value: if the animation adds its output value to the base value of the property being animated instead of replacing it; otherwise, . The default is .

MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool IsCumulative { bool get(); void set(bool value); };
member this.IsCumulative : bool with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that specifies whether the animation's value accumulates when it repeats.
Docs.value: if the animation accumulates its values when its property causes it to repeat its simple duration; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks When this property is set to `true`, the animation's output values only accumulate when the animation's <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Timeline.RepeatBehavior%2A> property causes it to repeat its simple duration. It does not accumulate its values when it restarts because its parent repeated or because its clock was restarted from a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.ClockController.Begin%2A> call.
